title: How has your concept of COVID-19 changed since you first heard of it to the present? - Quora

I am Australian and I support my prime minister as he is in a very difficult position but supports president Trump. I respect both leaders as they deal with Communist China and the Triad’s who may be in control. I don’t know. Thanks Rodney for asking. Initially my perception was that it is a pandemic no doubt (when President Trump declared it as a pandemic), but will not last long. The basic perception was about vaccine preparation. Also, it appeared a virus in lab that went berserk and spread (there were many theories about Wuhan-related spread). Then there was hue and cry that pilgrims were allowed to enter from Iran into Pakistan. That was the point when I started sniffing the trouble. I started reading about Spanish flu and the casualties. Worldometer has been providing country-wise detail (again the figures have been a debatable issue). Then clips on WhatsApp and social media started appearing about masking other deaths and enhancing death numbers under coronavirus. Again that raised eyebrows about authenticity of data. Then there were political problems and blame game started after German minister committed suicide. THAT WAS SOMETHING ALARMING. Italians were seen struggling and Spanish people followed with huge numbers. In the meantime Chinese managed to cap their deaths and fresh cases. Lockdowns played a big role in impacting economy adversely all over the globe. All this has its weight. Now I am afraid that this pandemic is going to last for another year may be more. I do not know but even if the numbers fail to depict exact dimension of catastrophe, we can label the problem as ‘very serious’. Thanks for reading the above.

At first, I considered it to be a novel virus, but similar to other diseases, where a person is contagious after the disease becomes spread throughout a person’s body to be obvious both to the person and to others. After all, we humans have a long history of being able to see the disease process at work, and we have learned to avoid contact and proximity to diseased people, in order to remain safe. I was wrong as wrong can be. Covid-19 is apparently highly contagious, when no symptoms are apparent in an infected person. Thus, all our experience has not prepared us to deal with this pandemic, and we need to behave differently than we are accustomed to behaving — if we are to manage the spread of the disease. So, yes my idea has changed. What I find insane is that so many people ignore this reality. This is a great social problem. I’ll leave it there, otherwise I will begin a toxic socio-political rant.
